cards.title: Rose McGowan / Sheila Wenzel did not fire me over Hollywood sexism tweet
cards.rawTitle: Sheila Wenzel did not fire me over Hollywood sexism tweet

item.title: Rose McGowan: Sheila Wenzel did not fire me over Hollywood sexism tweet
item.trailText: Actor and director made headlines after railing at a misogynist casting call for an Adam Sandler film, but says Wenzel had already left agency Innovative
item.standFirst: Actor and director made headlines after railing at a misogynist casting call for an Adam Sandler film, but says Wenzel had already left agency Innovative
item.body:
Rose McGowan has confirmed her agent Sheila Wenzel was not responsible for ‚Äúfiring‚Äù the actor and director in the wake of her critical comments regarding sexism in Hollywood.

It is understood Wenzel left agency Innovative prior to McGowan‚Äôs infamous tweet on June 17, in which she railed at a casting note calling for actors to show off their cleavage with pushup bras. She later revealed the call was for an unspecified Adam Sandler film.

Related: Rose McGowan 'fired by agent' for pointing out casting call sexism

McGowan made headlines around the world on Thursday when she tweeted that she had been ‚Äúfired‚Äù by her ‚Äúwussy acting agent‚Äù for pointing out ‚Äúthe bullshit in Hollywood‚Äù. The Hollywood Reporter later named her agents as Sheila Wenzel and Steve Muller at Innovative Artists.

However, the actor has since taken to Twitter to clarify that Wenzel was not involved in her departure, calling her ‚Äúa wonderful agent that ceased working with Innovative before my firing‚Äù. Wenzel also appeared to show support for McGowan on Twitter, retweeting a post in which the actor said the wonderful thing about being an artist was that ‚Äúyou can‚Äôt be fired from your own mind‚Äù.


Meanwhile, a report in Variety quotes a source at Sandler‚Äôs production company Happy Madison who denied all responsibility for the offending casting note. ‚ÄúThey were not aware the casting director sent this note out,‚Äù the source said. ‚ÄúThey felt it was completely inappropriate and have made sure that it has not been sent out again.‚Äù

Wenzel had also worked with Amanda Seyfried and Tomorrowland‚Äôs Britt Robertson at Innovative. On Thursday afternoon the under-fire agency issued a statement to the Hollywood Reporter confirming the departure. ‚ÄúSheila Wenzel, Rose McGowan‚Äôs primary agent, parted ways with Innovative before McGowan‚Äôs tweet yesterday,‚Äù the statement reads. ‚ÄúWenzel was not the primary agent for Amanda Seyfried and Britt Robertson.‚Äù

McGowan received support on Twitter yesterday from the Oscar-winning actor and feminist Jessica Chastain, who said her treatment confirmed ‚Äúthe misogyny underpinning the industry‚Äù.

headerImage.caption: Speaking out on sexism ... Rose McGowan has received support on Twitter from Jessica Chastain for her stance on Hollywood misogyny. Photograph: ROBYN BECK/AFP/Getty Images
headerImage.cleanCaption: Speaking out on sexism ... Rose McGowan has received support on Twitter from Jessica Chastain for her stance on Hollywood misogyny.

cards.title: Top five: Minions / You can never have too many ‚Ä¶
cards.rawTitle: You can never have too many ‚Ä¶

item.title: Top five: Minions
item.trailText: Top five Minions? How can you choose just five. If the Minions Movie teaches us anything, it‚Äôs that you can never have too many Minions. Here, then, are just a few top toys chosen by small people. Of the human, non-yellow variety
item.standFirst: Top five Minions? How can you choose just five. If the Minions Movie teaches us anything, it‚Äôs that you can never have too many Minions. Here, then, are just a few top toys chosen by small people. Of the human, non-yellow variety

displayImages.caption:
Talking Minion Bob, ¬£39.99
smythstoys.com

Child: ‚ÄúBob is my favourite Minion. This one talks lots to me in his funny Minion voice and he is cuddly and I love his teddy too. He blushes, too, but I don‚Äôt know why he is embarrassed. He shouldn‚Äôt be embarrassed when he is so cute, should he? Can I take him to bed with me or will he talk too much?‚Äù

Grownup: ‚ÄúNo film spoilers, but that news item about the Queen having to move out of Buckingham Palace? I think Bob needs to be asked about that ...‚Äù Photograph: PR company handout
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Talking Minion Bob, ¬£39.99
smythstoys.com

Child: ‚ÄúBob is my favourite Minion. This one talks lots to me in his funny Minion voice and he is cuddly and I love his teddy too. He blushes, too, but I don‚Äôt know why he is embarrassed. He shouldn‚Äôt be embarrassed when he is so cute, should he? Can I take him to bed with me or will he talk too much?‚Äù

Grownup: ‚ÄúNo film spoilers, but that news item about the Queen having to move out of Buckingham Palace? I think Bob needs to be asked about that ...‚Äù

displayImages.caption:
Inflatable Minion Stuart, ¬£38.95
geniegadgets.com

Children: ‚ÄúThis is BRILLIANT! Weeeeeeeee! [Kids squabble about who gets to drive Stuart.] You use the ‚Äômote control and it drives Stuart around really fast, forward and backwards and round in circles.‚Äù

Grownup: ‚ÄúThey should fix some kind of tray to this, I‚Äôd like Stuart to bring me a cup of tea. Or a G&T. That‚Äôs probably more despicable. A despicable inflatable yellow butler. More seriously, it‚Äôs a good toy, this, because although it‚Äôs pretty big when inflated, you can then deflate the actual Minion and put it away in a cupboard.‚Äù Photograph: PR image
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Inflatable Minion Stuart, ¬£38.95
geniegadgets.com

Children: ‚ÄúThis is BRILLIANT! Weeeeeeeee! [Kids squabble about who gets to drive Stuart.] You use the ‚Äômote control and it drives Stuart around really fast, forward and backwards and round in circles.‚Äù

Grownup: ‚ÄúThey should fix some kind of tray to this, I‚Äôd like Stuart to bring me a cup of tea. Or a G&T. That‚Äôs probably more despicable. A despicable inflatable yellow butler. More seriously, it‚Äôs a good toy, this, because although it‚Äôs pretty big when inflated, you can then deflate the actual Minion and put it away in a cupboard.‚Äù

displayImages.caption:
Soreen Minion lunchbox loaves, around ¬£1.30 for five pack
All major supermarkets

Children: [Silence, interrupted with scoffing noises]

Grownups: ‚ÄúSave me one! Ooh look you can win a party with the Minions. That sounds rather good. Do you think Gru will be there?‚Äù Photograph: PR image
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Soreen Minion lunchbox loaves, around ¬£1.30 for five pack
All major supermarkets

Children: [Silence, interrupted with scoffing noises]

Grownups: ‚ÄúSave me one! Ooh look you can win a party with the Minions. That sounds rather good. Do you think Gru will be there?‚Äù

displayImages.caption:
Minion Monopoly, ¬£19.99
smythstoys.com

Child [age 9]: ‚ÄúI love that you don‚Äôt get a dice like normal Monopoly, you get a Minion with a banana. It‚Äôs good for younger children, like my little brother, because it‚Äôs a bit simpler and the money isn‚Äôt worth as much, and the rules are easier to understand.‚Äù

Grownup: ‚ÄúReally great simple version of Monopoly. Quite pricey for a boardgame, I think, but we‚Äôve played it a lot already ‚Äì more than any other boardgame we‚Äôve got.‚Äù Photograph: PR image
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Minion Monopoly, ¬£19.99

displayImages.caption:
3D puzzle, ¬£5.87
amazon.co.uk

Child: ‚ÄúI‚Äôve never done a 3D-shaped puzzle before. It‚Äôs really shaped like a Minion! I finished it but I don‚Äôt want to put it away, I want to leave it out because I love Stuart, and it‚Äôs got a little stand so you can put him on a shelf‚Äù

Grownup: ‚ÄúThis is rather clever actually. It‚Äôs not big ‚Äì about 12cm tall, I think ‚Äì but a good price. There are more complicated ones, but I think 54 pieces is about right for my son‚Äôs attention span ‚Äì he‚Äôs seven. Not sure about the upper age being 99 mind. That‚Äôs discriminatory against centenarians, that is.‚Äù Photograph: PR company handout

cards.title: Cross-dressing covers / How paperbacks are being sexed up for the summer
cards.rawTitle: How paperbacks are being sexed up for the summer

item.title: Cross-dressing covers: how paperbacks are being sexed up for the summer
item.trailText: The jackets of last year‚Äôs big literary novels by male authors are undergoing a surprising seasonal transformation
item.standFirst: The jackets of last year‚Äôs big literary novels by male authors are undergoing a surprising seasonal transformation
item.body:
Visit your local bookshop as summer begins and you‚Äôll invariably find last year‚Äôs big literary novels have undergone a transformation. Formerly dressed up in hardback to look like serious contenders for prizes, they‚Äôre now eager to convince you that they‚Äôre ideal holiday reads, sexy without being brainless. This time, though, there‚Äôs a curious pattern to the way paperback jackets have been used to sex up the work of eminent male authors: they‚Äôre trying to persuade us they‚Äôre books about women.

In the case of Ian McEwan‚Äôs The Children Act, it really is, as discreetly reflected in a cover showing a woman (in a skirt and high heels) from the waist down walking on a rainy pavement. More striking are the movie poster-like jackets of Martin Amis‚Äôs The Zone of Interest, Richard Flanagan‚Äôs Booker winner The Narrow Road to the Deep North and Peter Carey‚Äôs Amnesia, in which women are love objects or professional collaborators but the protagonists are men. The hardbacks‚Äô abstract or symbolic images have been replaced by variants of the same image ‚Äì a woman gazes out at you, but the jacket‚Äôs left edge cuts her face in half so that only one eye is visible.

In paperbacks of current literary novels that actually are about (and are usually by) women, there is less agreement on how to attract time-rich summer readers. Some adopt a period pastiche look (Sarah Waters), or go for the single symbols more common on men‚Äôs jackets (Eimear McBride, Kate Atkinson). Clutter ‚Äì covers crammed with words or images (Emma Healey, Jessie Burton) ‚Äì is this season‚Äôs trend. Colours and compositions are low-key, and if female figures do appear they tend to be tiny silhouettes or (Colm Tóibín, Elena Ferrante) have their backs turned ‚Äì someone unsettlingly gazing at you is unthinkable in female lit fic, although it‚Äôs fine for EL James‚Äôs Grey, erotica written from a male perspective.

So an unlikely form of cross-dressing has taken place, whereby leading male authors‚Äô novels misleadingly brand themselves as women-centric while their female counterparts‚Äô books are downplaying their heroines‚Äô gender. But all the single eyes, detached legs, turned backs and inanimate symbols are linked by a peculiar implicit consensus that if jackets show women‚Äôs whole faces or bodies they repel readers. If you scan a bookshop‚Äôs fiction table this weekend, you‚Äôll find that only one novel begs to differ, standing out in design as it does in originality: two young women, facing our way and shown from the waist up, appear (in both hardback and paperback) on the cover of Ali Smith‚Äôs How to Be Both, winner of the Goldsmiths, Costa first novel and Baileys women‚Äôs fiction prizes.

displayImages.caption: Sexy but not brainless ‚Ä¶ former prize contenders are being dressed up as ideal holiday reads. Photograph:"   Steven Errico/Corbis
displayImages.altText: Person reading a book on the beach
displayImages.cleanCaption: Sexy but not brainless ‚Ä¶ former prize contenders are being dressed up as ideal holiday reads. Photograph:"   Steven Errico/Corbis

cards.title: Neil Young + Promise of the Real / The Monsanto Years review ‚Äì on angry, brilliant form
cards.rawTitle: The Monsanto Years review ‚Äì on angry, brilliant form

item.title: Neil Young + Promise of the Real: The Monsanto Years review ‚Äì on angry, brilliant form
item.trailText: Neil Young‚Äôs anti-GM, anti-Starbucks, generally anti-corporate album proves he is still a force to be reckoned with
item.body:
Related: Raging in the free world: the many furies of Neil Young

An anti-GM food concept album by Neil Young may not seem a thrilling prospect, I grant you. But although People Want to Hear About Love, as he acknowledges on his song of that title, shouldn‚Äôt he talk about ‚Äúthe corporations hijacking all your rights‚Äù, too? And on-form and on-song ‚Äì as he undoubtedly is here (he also has a pop at Starbucks, Walmart and Safeway) ‚Äì Young is still a force to be reckoned with. There is urgency and energy here: ‚ÄúToo big to fail / Too rich for jail,‚Äù he sings on Big Box. It has certainly rattled the pro-GM lobby ‚Äì Tory former minister Owen Paterson has attacked the ‚Äúageing songwriter‚Äù for his stance. He‚Äôs backed on his 36th album by Promise of the Real, an LA band featuring Willie Nelson‚Äôs sons Lukas and Micah. They sound not unlike Crazy Horse, and supply all the big riffs, crashing major chords and harmonies that have characterised Young‚Äôs best records for five decades.

headerImage.caption: He‚Äôs got em rattled ‚Ä¶ Neil Young
headerImage.cleanCaption: He‚Äôs got em rattled ‚Ä¶ Neil Young

kicker.title: Neil Young + Promise of the Real

cards.title: Viral video chart / Channing Tatum, Lionel Messi, Shakira and Greg James
cards.rawTitle: Channing Tatum, Lionel Messi, Shakira and Greg James

item.title: Viral video: Channing Tatum, Lionel Messi, Shakira and Greg James
item.trailText: Radio 1 presenter rounds up the Minions, the history of hip-hop, Cristiano Ronaldo in a WWE clash with Draco Malfoy, and the cat in the flap
item.standFirst: Radio 1 presenter rounds up the Minions, the history of hip-hop, Cristiano Ronaldo in a WWE clash with Draco Malfoy, and the cat in the flap
item.body:
Pilot Romain Jantot thought he had carried out all the correct pre-flight checks before taking a passenger for a flying experience. But he hadn‚Äôt reckoned on a stowaway cat which suddenly appeared over the wing after he had taken off. After the flight, Jantot said: ‚ÄúI told my passenger not to reach for the cat. I told her not to move at all actually. I trusted the cat to not move if we didn‚Äôt try to reach for her.‚Äù You can catch another plucky pussy who scared off an Alaskan brown bear here.

If you are missing the football season, you will love our clip of 15-year-old Lionel Messi when he played for Barcelona‚Äôs Under-16 squad in the 2002/03 season. The footage was released to mark the player‚Äôs 28th birthday.

There‚Äôs more youthful talent on show when Channing Tatum and Jimmy Fallon read scenes written by elementary school kids. The Tonight show supplied the title Magic Mike and the young viewers had to write the rest. The kiddie theme continues with BBC Radio 1‚Äôs Greg James having to look after some Minions and a mock WWE fight between Cristiano Ronaldo and the Harry Potter character Draco Malfoy.

If you are hoping for a musical interlude, check out Shakira on a water hoverboard ‚Äì she says she did get higher but that‚Äôs not in the video ‚Äì and the Polish National Radio Symphony Orchestra performing a 30-song medley of some of the most influential hip-hop hits from the past 20 years. Arranged and conducted by Radzimir Dƒôbski ‚Äì better known as JIMEK ‚Äì the 10-minute-long arrangement opens up with Kendrick Lamar‚Äôs Swimming Pools and includes classic tracks such as Dr Dre‚Äôs Still D.R.E. and Missy Elliott‚Äôs Get Your Freak On. It‚Äôs a treat!

1) Remove cat before flight
Cat flap

2) Kid Theater with Channing Tatum
Once upon a time ‚Ä¶

3) Messi with FC Barcelona‚Äôs U-16 team
Don‚Äôt Messi with me

4) Greg James: Mind My Minions
James in a jam

5) Hip-Hop History Orchestrated by JIMEK
Dre-mendous

6) Cristiano Ronaldo Vs Draco Malfoy
Super power clash

7) I did fly higher
Shakira rides the waves

8) Pups running for dinner, timelapse style
Hungry years

9) How to dock like a boss
Safe but not sound

10) Think!
The joy of helping others

cards.title: Taylor Swift review / Intimacy on a grand scale from pop's latest superpower
cards.rawTitle: Intimacy on a grand scale from pop's latest superpower

item.title: Taylor Swift review ‚Äì intimacy on a grand scale from pop's latest superpower
item.trailText: The giant screens capture the occasional goofy grin or eye-roll, a hint that Swift is aware of the ridiculousness of all this excess
item.standFirst:
SSE Hydro, Glasgow

The giant screens capture the occasional goofy grin or eye-roll, a hint that Swift is aware of the ridiculousness of all this excess
item.body:
In 2015, most pop stars strive to break the internet. Taylor Swift seems intent on fixing it. She zaps trolls by broadcasting positivity to millions of fans on her matrix of social media channels, and with one sharply worded Tumblr post, shamed Apple into a U-turn on freezing artist payments during the launch of its new streaming service.

She‚Äôs perhaps the most influential artist on the planet, then, but also laser-focused on phase two of an already impressive career. Swift‚Äôs migration from Nashville pop-country to New York pop-with-a-capital-P is complete, so this world tour is a tailored victory lap for her fifth album 1989, the launchpad for the irresistible Shake It Off and witty hook-up/breakup ballad Blank Space. With a dozen buff dancers and retina-scorching staging, even the minor tracks are punched up into stand-alone blockbusters, though Swift herself remains the most impressive indoor firework.

She skips through a ballet of doorways on castors during I Know Places, pirouettes in a neon summer dress for How You Get the Girl and even negotiates scaffolding while delivering the throaty battle cries of Bad Blood. If that suggests a cold, Terminator-style professionalism, the giant screens also capture the occasional goofy grin or eye-roll, a hint that Swift is aware of the ridiculousness of all this art-directed excess, but that won‚Äôt stop her from enjoying it. It‚Äôs a series of knowing winks that invites 12,000 fans to share in the fun.

Around 75 minutes of music is rolling-pinned out into a 140-minute extravaganza, with pitstops required for costume changes and stage resetting. These lulls are offset by entertaining pre-recorded testimonials from Swift‚Äôs posse of five-star pals, including Lena Dunham, Cara Delevingne and Haim. Even her two cats get a cameo.

Video inserts aside, Swift emphatically leads from the front. During a series of solo songs, she‚Äôs raised into the centre of the arena bowl on a hydraulic neon seesaw, floating in an impromptu starfield of audience-issued glowing bracelets like some sort of sun god. Swift framed in such an awe-inducing manner while she delivers mini-sermons about the importance of how to deal with heartbreak and be true to yourself gives this gig the air of a pop megachurch. But it also means fans, old and young, get plenty of face time with an enchanting but relatable idol. It‚Äôs a masterclass in inclusivity.

  • At British Summer Time, Hyde Park, London on 27 June.

displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Ross Gilmore/Getty Images for TAS

bodyImages.caption: Taylor Swift in Glasgow. Photograph: Ross Gilmore/Getty Images for TAS
bodyImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Ross Gilmore/Getty Images for TAS

headerImage.cleanCredit: Photograph: Ross Gilmore/Getty Images for TAS

image.cleanCredit: Photograph: Ross Gilmore/Getty Images for TAS

cards.title: Business jargon ‚Äì the 10 words to avoid at all costs
cards.rawTitle: Business jargon ‚Äì the 10 words to avoid at all costs

item.title: Business jargon ‚Äì the 10 words to avoid at all costs
item.trailText: Is your business disruptive and dynamic? It‚Äôs time to find another way to describe it
item.standFirst: Is your business disruptive and dynamic? It‚Äôs time to find another way to describe it
item.body:
‚ÄúTo leverage this opportunity for ROI we need to value add through R&D and core competencies, let‚Äôs touch base offline.‚Äù

Confused? So‚Äôs your client. Acronyms and business jargon are gathering speed and taking over everyday office chat. If you assume everyone is au fait with ‚Äúthought showers‚Äù and ‚Äúblue sky thinking‚Äù you could well be alienating (and irritating) people the moment you open your mouth.

We asked our readers which words and phrases send them into meltdown, and this is what they came up with:

Disruptive

It‚Äôs not just us, everyone knows disruptive is a really annoying word. A repeat offender in the world of press releases, it‚Äôs become ubiquitous lately ‚Äì but what does it mean? Well, nothing really.

Use instead: new, innovative

Synergy

Here‚Äôs another one that‚Äôs nothing more than hot air.

Use instead: work together

Annual leave

Ok, so everyone understands this, but I‚Äôve never understood why we can‚Äôt just say holiday.

Use instead: holiday.

Upskill

As a word, training was clearly too prosaic, so a nifty new verbal mashup was created.

Use instead: training

Value add

A perfectly reasonable phrase has been switched round, causing readers‚Äô hackles to rise in the process.

Use instead: add value, improve

Blue sky thinking

A blue sky has none of those pesky clouds to limit your boundless creativity ‚Ä¶ or something like that.

Use instead: original, creative

Generation Y/Z/Millennials

Targeting the 18 to 24 age group? Just say what you mean, and everyone will be grateful.

Use instead: age

Leverage

People are using this pointless word in their droves. Please don‚Äôt use ‚Äúutilise‚Äù either.

Use instead: use

Dynamic

Probably the least offensive term on this list, but to be avoided nonetheless. Understand what a ‚Äúdynamic website‚Äù or ‚Äúdynamic strategy‚Äù is? Didn‚Äôt think so.

Use instead: exciting/new

Touch base

One of many phrases stolen from the world of sport (see below) ‚Äì but this one is particularly irritating on account of its vagueness. It‚Äôs not as concrete as meeting up, and is guaranteed to be a waste of time.

Use instead: meet

And here‚Äôs what you said

Have you been offended by a particularly toxic example of business jargon? Share it with us in the comments section
